target_text: "We aim for clean code. This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines. We also aim for sustainability of the design. This means the software design is able to cope with new requirements easily moving forward."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

Codebook.role: Reflective Software-Quality Researcher (Doctoral; CS/Software Engineering; NSF interest: sustainable software & quality; Biases: standards-oriented, long-termism)

codebook.justification: [We aim for clean code.] As a standards-oriented SE scholar, “clean” is a normative aesthetic, negotiated by teams and communities rather than objectively fixed.
Anchored by [maintainable code]. Maintainability is interpretive—shaped by conventions, tooling, and experience—without a single definitive metric.
Cued by [well established guidelines]. Which guidelines are privileged and how strictly they’re construed are subjective, reflecting methodological allegiances.
Signaled by [cope with new requirements easily]. My long-termism bias foregrounds evolvability; judgments of “ease” and acceptable change cost are context-dependent.
